comments.commentBody: Yes, the irony of that statement was pretty rich. I wonder if most prosecutors feel that way or if this article just found some that did. I like to think that people who work closely with public defenders on a daily basis -- and who presumably have an interest in justice for all -- have a better sense of what fair is in the adversarial system.

But some prosecutors remain skeptical. The study has “little value,” said Eric G. Zahnd, the prosecuting attorney in Platte County, because the panel of lawyers estimating needs had “every incentive to inflate the number of hours it takes to handle any given case.”

And, I am sure. Mr. Zahnd also has every incentive to force as many more cases as possible into a few private defenders. Prosecutors, by his same logic, I am sure Mr. Zahnd agrees, also have "every incentive" to maximize their own prosecutorial incarceration success rates by making public defenders as ineffectual as possible.
Like "professional wrestling", these events are increasingly parodies of genuine sport designed for mass (big money) entertainment, not genuine sporting competition.
The EITC is no different than the other subsidies corporations receive because they do not pay their employees a living wage: food stamps, Medicaid, and housing assistance.

RLS, that's true, but you're thinking in terms of morality rather than economic practicality, e.g., "it's morally wrong for corporations to pay their employees so little."

We have to be a bit conceptual about how the economic system works. Gobalization has created an oversupply of low-level workers and pushed down wages and weakened the union movement. Executives are earning much too much, but companies aren't going to stop doing that, since they executives sit on one another's boards.

The EIC allows us to shift some income from the rich executives to the poor workers, and does so without creating perverse incentives that force people out of work, and without the downward pressure on total employment created by the minimum wage. So it would be a better deal for the worker and it would result in greater fairness. But, as I said, the Republicans would have to agree to raise taxes or increase the deficit.

The Republicans are forever claiming that anything that benefits workers will damage the economy, and forever being wrong. For one thing, the American economy is usually limited by sluggish consumer demand rather than productive capacity, and that problem has been particularly acute during the recession. The rich spend less of their earnings than the poor, so income redistribution will tend to push up demand.

Are the Republicans entirely wrong? No. For the most part, businesses employ only as many workers as they need, and so will tend to raise prices rather than dismiss them. But, obviously, there will be some pressure on jobs. One solution would be to expand the earned income tax credit in lieu of raising the minimum wage, but this would require a willingness on the part of Republcans to increase the deficit or raise taxes on the rich.
Men and women are physically different period. It's just the way we evolved. I see nothing wrong with modifying sporting fields to match. Just common sense people.

Woman athletes do get paid less.

Usually their advertising contracts pay less, too.

Watching the slopestyle athletes it seemed to me that the power for their performance came from the steep dips on the course. The body is held rigid - the stiffer the better.A lot of skill is needed to do this, but to me the Olympics means using the body - not denying it movement.
Except that Bode Miller had no problem with the interviewer and said as much.  She was a friend of his and he actually told the media 'I have no problem with the interview please leave her alone."
You're exactly right about that Bode Miller interview.  My husband and I were both yelling at the TV: "Leave him alone!  What's WRONG with you people?"
The reporter went too far and should have been reprimanded for her insensitive questioning.

Just turned-off NBC's Olympics for the second and final time. First during the over-the-top exploitative and voyeuristic Bode Miller interview on Sunday, and tonight during the sadistic showing of an injured American half-pipe skier. NBC - I am embarrassed and disgusted. You represent the worst of the American media, perfectly.
The next question is - do daredevil (clearly dangerous) sports belong in the Olympics?

Thats right Ed Lasky, nobody forces those women and they're doing terrific. They're smaller and weaker than men, yet they are doing the same sport the same way with the same conditions and winning gold silver and bronze!!!! They take their falls and they get up, brush off and keep going!

It's a daredevil sport. What's the point in making it safer? If some women are afraid of the danger, then maybe they shouldn't participate. Nobody forces
them.
Why on earth do you guys keep bringing up combat?  Is snowboarding a new infantry requirement?

Equality means equal opportunity.  I've been a lifelong participant and advocate for women in sports but women do not have the strength or muscle mass that men do.  Testosterone and Estrogen are not the same nor a the physical abilities (requiring strength) the same between the sexes.  Women should be able to compete at the highest level but for the same reason women don't use the rings or parallel bars in gymnastics, I can see the need for certain adjustments here as well.  I'm no fan of these x-games "sports" and wouldn't miss them if they disappeared from the Olympics....seems there have been more deaths among these athletes (male and female) than your average alpine sport/race.
exactly!

Putin like Stalin wants to control Ukraine. It has resources , fertile lands , a port on the Black Sea and the natural gas pipeline from Russia to Europe runs through Ukraine . Who is going to step in to save the part of the Ukraine that is not dominated by Russians . This is a sad story that is a repeat of history in the 1930's.
Audrey

@Dick Diamond - I don't think you understand the divisions in Ukraine it's not as simple as the Western press is trying to paint  - East vs. West , Orthodox vs Catholic ( that part is laughable) not even Ukrainian vs. Russian speaking. I know people who are at the protests and there are many who are Russian speaking because it's not about the old nationalistic order, it's about the government corruption, about not having a voice, lack of chances for young people , etc. This is why most of the protesters are young people. Sure some other factions have a vested interest in getting rid of current government as well but it is oversimplifying to say that's the old division. Most Ukrainians would be appalled that the West is already divvying the country up in 2 parts.

Western Ukraine has the minority of population in the Country.  I think people in eastern and southern Ukraine, who make up the majority of the Country, may have a slightly different psyche, although I wouldn't the one to judge.

Pure and simple, this is about Ukraine extracting itself from centuries of Russian domination. And, the Russians will do everything in their power to prevent that. It is not about economics, democracy, security, etc. My family is from western Ukraine, and I am part of the first generation born in America. Nobody can truly understand the Ukrainian psyche without sharing the blood ties and cultural links.
Just wondering - what's the reasoning for yeses for N.Korea and Syria, but Ukraine?
This one is none of our business so I hope President Obama doesn't come out and put his foot in his mouth on this. N. Korea, yes.....Syria, yes.....Not this one.
they are not minority either.

Our country is coming more and more to resemble some lesser beast; a chimera of sorts – part UK, with their invasive and heavy-handed use of technology to spy on everyone and part PRC, with the interests of government/business held paramount to the interests of the individual or society.

I don't believe that this application of technology is needed or will make anyone safer or more productive.
If the taxes are restored to the rather simple formula used during the 1950's there will be lots of money to pay unemployment and at sums people can live on while they seek new jobs.
If the taxes are restored to the rather simple formula used during the 1950's there will be lots of money to pay unemployment and at sums people can live on while they seek new jobs.
What will happen to families of those 500,000 people who will lose their jobs? Is it OK to let them go deeper in poverty?
Add the 'defense' department to the list. Keep a few for disaster relief. Mothball the rest and double SS and means test it.

DocMorgan:

Means testing Social Security is not a good idea. The program was created as an earned right where benefits are determined by the contributions. There is no law that forces wealthy Americans to claim their benefits and they only make up a very small portion of the population, so disqualifying them from receiving Social Security will not make much of an impact on the program’s finances. It would, however, undermine support for it.

Every excuse in the book, not to raise the minimum wage.
Yes there will be a period of adjustment, maybe some marginal businesses will go under and it may be inflationary.

Stop stepping on the little guy. Everybody and his brother is ripping us off.
Every politician should be replaced.
The 85 people that have half the earth's wealth is beyond
comprehension.
Obama the disappointment, doesn't use the bully pulpit near enough to do social good.
Maybe he should stop talking to the spy's and focus on the people.
For the life of me I can't see the good that the CIA, DEA, or Homeland Security, does for our well being.

The poor do not have enough to spend without living poorly, eating junk and paying high rents. You raise to $10 and the landlord will raise the rent and they'll still be trapped. Kids at home, part time $10. Adults $20 and up and freeze those rents.

Remember the poor spend and the wealthy save. By putting $5 billion in the hands of the poorest Americans that's almost a guarantee that every dollar in wages will be put right back into the economy. And they won't be spending that $5 billion at Peter Lugers or Neiman Marcus, they'll be spending it at inexpensive places McDonalds and Old Navy ( where I'm guessing that sales people make near minimum wage).

Sounds good, but a majority of people earning minimum wage are in families with incomes more than 400% of the poverty level. I think the number is about 16% of the people working minimum wage jobs actually live below the poverty level. directed aid is a better option, and it won't cause the loss of 500,000 jobs.

Take the study at face value and ask whether the net result is good for the country. A loss of some jobs, of low income, compared with a larger gain of income at the bottom end of the income distribution, apparently means more economic growth. Not that that is necessarily all that compelling an objective! But by current standards it is clearly the way to go for most people. So, once again, the Republicans are on the wrong side.

You’re right. “[I]ncreasing minimum wage will increase prices to such an extent as to negate any positive effects” is a bogus argument. Higher wages gives consumers greater purchasing power and improves the economy.

Research Shows that a Rise in the Minimum Wage Does Not Cause Job Loss: http://therealnews.com/t2/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&amp...

“One of the simple facts that we’ve come up with in PERI in our research around the minimum wage is that actually when you look at the ‘cost that businesses face when the minimum wage goes up,’ the costs are actually QUITE MODEST. And that’s what explains why there isn't some big negative, you know, job loss that you can associate with any minimum-wage hike. This is something that we try to make clear but seems to get lost in the debate.

“An average restaurant could cover the cost of a 30 percent minimum-wage increase by raising their prices by *1 PERCENT.*

“Because clearly the minimum wage right now, $7.25, even the proposed $9 an hour minimum-wage proposal by President Obama, those wages are too low to sustain families. So what we need to be thinking more carefully about is how much more could we raise the minimum wage in order to find a sustainable wage for families.”

I love how some people are convinced that increasing minimum wage will increase prices to such an extent as to negate any positive effects for families living on minimum wage in addition to causing the economy at large additional harm, despite the fact that this has been completely debunked by observation, and no economist will stand by this claim. How does an increase in price for fast food and consumables purchased at retailers like Walmart or Target negate the increased ability of a family to pay rent, pay for transportation, internet, healthcare, or education? This argument should be put to rest.

SInce over 60% of new jobs in the US since the 2007 recession pay the low wages of McDs and Walamrt

Since the largest group of new jobs in the future will be those paying McDs and Walmart wages

Why should I - who never sets foot in fast food places or Walmart - have to pay taxes that go to feed the McDs and Walamrt workers when those companies are making billions and can be the real cost of keeping their workers alive with housing and food?

Actually Dave, that blah blah about some baised and skweed nonsense from the U of Chicago (a place that I, from personal experience, know to have less than a good grasp of reality), is - to quote Col. Potter of MASH - a laod of horse hockey.

Well over the majority - the vast vast over 75% majority - of sutdies have found that increasing the minimum wage has a de minmis impact on the employment rate. Ya know - de minimis as in the theorettical .05% projected by the CBO
Discussing, realistically, the physical differences between men and women is not paternalistic. If men and women were the same, they would be competeing against one another, not separately.

Contrary to widespread opinion many lawyers actually believe their court suits, brief filings and appeals on behalf of banks, hedge funds and other moneyed interests are interesting, noble and important, which explains why so few of them are drawn to legal aid work, where notwithstanding the dismal pay, lawyers are required to deal on a day-to-day basis with real world problems never dreamed of at the Harvard Law School.
